titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Captain Symonds was here again this morning— This man appears incapable of transacting his own business; and yet is entrusted with the property of others. He consents however to leave his ship under the charge of his mate, but claims the payment of his own wages— I asked him to make out his accounts, and produce his vouchers, and promised if I found them sufficient to use my endeavours to assist him.— I walked through the Summer-Gardens which are in all the nakedness of Winter; and entirely deserted except by the crows, and the servants who sweep into heaps the fallen leaves— Dined with Messrs: W. S. Smith, Everett and Gray, at Mr: Raimbert’s— Mr: Anderson, Dr: Pitt, the English clergyman, & Mr: Rodde of Riga were there— Mr: Harris; with Messrs: Jones and J. S. Smith dined at the Grand-Veneur Narichkin’s— Between 10. & 11 I went to the French Ambassador’s and spent about three hours there— The Company was of about seventy or eighty persons. Mlle: George, the actress, her younger Sister the dancer, Mr: Duport, Mr: & Madame Baptiste, Mr: & Madame Lafon were there. Miss George declaimed Scenes from Athalie—Les Horaces, and Phedre— Her Sister, Mr: & Madame Batiste, and Mr Duport, danced minuets and fancy dances— The rest of the Company at the intervals danced as at an ordinary Ball— I came home between one and two in the morning— Count Romanzoff, Prince Kurakin, Grand Maréchal Tolstoy, and all the Narishkin’s were there en frac. Captain Uvaroff told me that the Command of his Regiment was given to the Grand Duke Constantine upon which I made him my compliments—

2. I rode round upon the Vasily Ostroff, going over the Bridge at the Isaac’s square, and returning by that opposite the Summer Gardens— Confined at home all the remainder of the day by the weather— Having again a little leisure time I am undertaking to resume the practice of writing in short hand— I have at various periods of my life spent not a little time in acquiring this habit but have never used it for any valuable purpose— There have been however numerous occasions upon which it would have been highly useful to me had I possessed it with sufficient readiness— I wrote to Mr: Bacon & read Levesque Vol. 3— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr Fisher were here in the Evening.

3. Mr: Fisher last Evening left his pocket-book in his surtout pocket, in one of our anti-chambers— The pocket-book contained three fifty ruble bank-bills, which were stolen from it; and the theft must have been committed, to all appearance, either by John Berndt, a footman whom I have lately taken into service or by Waldstein my steward— John came to me this morning in great agitation and told his story— The surtout was left in his custody—the pocket-book fell from the pocket on the floor—he picked it up and looked into it; and says that there were in it three one hundred ruble bills— But Mr: Fisher himself says they were fifty ruble bills— Waldstein afterwards came, took the surtout from the first into the second anti-chamber, and sent John below upon some errand. When he returned, he says he found the surtout restored to its first place— He looked again into the pocket-book, and found the bills were gone— He was so much terrified that he did not tell Mr: Fisher of it when he went away; but immediately after went & waked Pierre who was gone to bed; told him of it, and asked his advice what to do— Pierre told him to wait untill the morning, and then if he was innocent to go to Mr: Fisher and tell him the story. He went accordingly this morning— Mr: Fisher was in bed; and found upon examining his pocket-book that the money was gone. John charges Waldstein with having taken the money while he was gone below. But he cannot justify himself for having opened the pocket-book, or for neglecting to tell Mr: Fisher that the money was gone, when he went away— Waldstein declares that he did not know there was a pocket-book, or money in the pocket— Mr: Harris called on me in the course of the morning, and I had some conversation with him respecting the course to be taken in this business— I took however no final resolution upon the subject— Madame Colombi and her sister Clementine, with Don Francisco Colombi, her husband’s brother spent the Evening with us; but went away before supper. Mr: J. S. Smith, Mr: Jones and Mr: Everett supped with us, and the party did not break up untill nearly one in the morning.

4. John the footman came again this morning, and urged for a further examination into the affair of the money stolen from Mr: Fisher’s Pocket-book, in which his character is deeply implicated— Waldstein was desirous of the same thing; and I told them I must refer them both to-morrow to the police.— I had a visit this forenoon from Mr: Boucher, who appears to be much mortified at the ill-success
of his course of lectures— I think him more agreeable in conversation than as a lecturer— He intends however to pronounce a discourse at one of his Evenings, of which he said he would give further notice, and which he invited me to attend. I walked to the foundery, and observed the setting of the Sun from the stand opposite the palace door on the Quay, which I took at the Summer Solstice to mark the full extent of its declination— It now sits in a line from that stand directly down the river, and over the middle of the lower Bridge of Boats— In the Evening we had visits from Mr: Labensky, and from Count Luxbourg. The Ladies spent the Evening after 10. O’Clock at the Duchess de Serra Capriola’s— I read Massillon’s panegyric upon St: Louis— His Satire upon the Great, his abhorrence of Theatres and his veneration for the crusades appear again in this discourse, which contains some good reflections, but few of the author’s peculiarities of Style— In the Evening I read Robinson’s character of Balaam, and Bishop Butler’s Sermon upon the same personage— I have often heard my father speak of this Sermon in terms of very high approbation— I do not think so much of it myself— My father has so strong and reflecting a mind, that I always distrust my own judgment when it differs from his— But I think he overrates some of the books, which he first read in early life, and which opened to his mind philosophical views of nature, by no means uncommon, but which struck him most forcibly because they were new to him— Butler’s Balaam is a rough, unfinished and very imperfect sketch of a strange and mysterious character in the Bible— To illustrate that inconsistency of human nature, by which a man sees and approves the right, while he pursues the wrong— But it does not elucidate as I think it might the Story of Balaam, and it is written in a careless and slovenly style— It gives an exposition of a passage in the prophet Micah respecting Balaam, which is at least questionable, and according to Ostervald’s french Bible not admissible— I read also in the English preacher a sermon upon the character of Haman, far inferior to that of Blair.

5. Waldstein and John went this morning to the police— Waldstein had been there first, and entered a complaint against John, for charging him with having stolen Mr. Fisher’s money— John was much incensed at this, and very unwilling to go to the Police—insisting that he was to have been Waldstein’s accuser, and that he did not wish to go to the police in any other manner— He had got intoxicated and behaved insolently to me; but I told him I would send for a Police Officer to come and take him, he became humble and went to the Police— They examined him, and detained him for further examination untill to-morrow morning.— Mr: Grammann, who called upon me the day before yesterday, this morning sent me some English Caricatures.— The Ladies spent the Evening and supp’d at Madame Colombi’s— I went there myself about 10 O’Clock and pass’d a couple of hours— General Betancourt and his family were there; Baroness Strogonoff, Count Lüxbourg, and the Chevalier Navarro.— Mr: W. Smith dined abroad.

6. I went this morning to the police-Office, and stated to the Officer there the Circumstances upon which Waldstein and John had been there for examination, and I expressed my wish that both of them might be examined alike upon Oath— The Officer said that besides the examination of them personally, it would be necessary to search their chambers, which being in my house could not be done without my permission, which I accordingly gave him— He said it would also be necessary to ascertain where he had been since the affair happened, and whether he had paid money to any body— Just as I was going out I received a note from Count Romanzoff, enclosing a packet from Mr: Russell, whom General Armstrong has left charged with the Affairs of the United States at Paris. I had not time to read the letters untill I returned— There were also letters for Messrs: Cramer, and for Mr J. S. Smith, which I carried to them. At Mr: Smith’s chambers I saw Mr: Lewis, who proposes to go through Sweden to Gothenburg, and thence to England; who requested me to procure for him a Courier’s Passport, and offered to take my despatches— Mr: Fisher too was there, and went to the Police-Office to be examined— Mr: Grammann called upon me again, and brought with him some English newspapers to the 25th: of September— As he wished to have them returned to-morrow I was engaged the whole Evening in reading them— All the Gentlemen of the legation, Mr: Jones & Mr: Harris pass’d part of the Evening with us— They (excepting Mr Harris) and the Ladies at Cards— Mrs: Adams was very unwell all the Evening, and in the Night.

7. I sent to enquire this morning, if Mr: Navarro was at his lodgings; intending to call on him, and tell him of the opportunity of sending to England by Mr: Lewis, for whom I propose to ask a Courier’s Passport from Count Romanzoff— Mr: Navarro sent me word & was at home, and I was going to his apartments when I met Mr: Montréal on the stairs, who was coming to see me— I returned with him; and
soon afterwards Mr: Navarro himself called upon me— I had afterwards a visit from Mr: Jones— I employed as much of the day as was left in writing, to send by Mr: Lewis; and also the Evening— We were to have spent it at General Betancourt’s but both Mrs: Adams and Catherine being unwell we were obliged to send an apology— Catherine is confined to her chamber.

8. The weather being this morning very fine, a circumstance unusual here at any season of the year, and especially at this, I took a walk to the foundery before breakfast— I saw the Sun when about ten minutes risen, for I found no place from which I could see it rise— From my usual stand it rises directly behind the palace— Mr: Fisher and Mr: Lewis called on me this forenoon— I wrote to Count Romanzoff requesting a Courier’s Passport for Mr: Lewis— The remainder of the day and Evening untill 9. O’Clock I was engaged in writing to America— Then dressed and went with Mrs: Adams to the French Ambassador’s— He has this Winter an Evening party every Thursday— This Evening besides the Ball, he entertained his Company with two little french Operas, performed by the actors of the french theatre— Dix jours de mariage; ou rien de trop— And les Rendéz-vous Bourgeois.— They were well performed, and amusing though somewhat licentious pieces— The Grand-Maitre des Cérémonies invited me to go and see the Palace of Annitchke, which the Emperor has just given to the Grand duchess Catherine; and appointed Saturday, one O’Clock afternoon, for that purpose— Soon after the play was over, between one and two in the morning we came home.

9. I rose this morning later than usual, and from the hour of rising, untill 9 in the Evening was employed in preparing despatches to go by Mr: Lewis— I kept Mr: W. S. Smith and Mr: Everett also both employed the whole day in making copies— Mr: Morse came for a Passport which I gave him— Mr: Harris was also here this forenoon— Count Romanzoff sent me a Courier’s Passport for Mr: Lewis, but without the order for the horses— I wrote him therefore a note requesting that order which he sent me in the Evening. He also sent me an Official Note in answer to mine of 21. October to him; of which I sent translations with my despatches to the Secretary of State— I wrote to my father, and to Mr: W. Pinkney in London— Mr Lewis called with Mr: Fisher, about ten O’Clock this Evening, and I gave him all my packets for Gothenburg, and for London; together with those of Mr: Navarro, which he sent me early in the Evening.— I found yesterday morning the Canals frozen over; and this morning all the bridges have been taken away— The ice is forming in the river very fast, and in three or four days more it will probably be fixed. General de Betancourt’s Lady and daughters were here in the Evening.

10. Mr: Lewis and Mr: Morse, succeeded in crossing the river with their Carriage this morning, although the ice continues to make in the river very fast— At one O’Clock I went to the Palace of St: Ann, by invitation from the Grand-Maitre des Céremonies, who was there— Mrs: Adams did not go in— The French Ambassador and his Secretaries, Rayneval, St: Genest and Prevost were there—Count Schenk and Baron Schladen—Madame de Vlodek, with her husband and Sisters, and some other Ladies— The Palace is very elegantly furnished, and all new; but the Grand Duchess left the City last Monday, on her return to Twer.— As the principal part of the furniture and particularly the bronzes were made here, the Ambassador and all his Secretaries were eagle-eyed to discover their defects and made no secret of their discoveries.— The perfection of the work here is certainly not equal to that of the workmen at Paris, but it requires much refinement in the arts of luxury to discern so readily the difference between them— Some of the tapestry was of Lyons velvet— A breakfast service in gold, very well worked— The only pictures were a Bog—the head of Christ—and a small full length portrait of St: Alexander Newsky— The chapel is neat, and provided with all the articles used in the Russian form of worship. After returning from this visit I walked to the foundery, and met General Pardo upon the Quay— The ice was floating down the river, and the General said that the waters had such a propensity to freezing, that they hardly waited for the formality of a cold day to turn solid— Mrs: Adams went this Evening to the French theatre— I spent it at home, reading the Moniteur and practicing short-hand.

11. Mr: Rodde came this morning, and brought me a letter from Mr: Gray of Boston, which he had just received from Reval, with several letters for Mr: F. Gray— But their date was of 7. July, previous to the departure of Mr: Jones— I wrote to the Police Officer, requesting that if after the examination of my servant John, and the search of his chamber there was not evidence to prove his guilt beyond a doubt, he might be discharged— Mr: Harris dined with us— General Watzdorf, Mr: J. S. Smith, and Mr Jones were here in
the Evening— I wrote part of a letter to the Secretary of State, and read Massillon’s Panegyric of St: Stephen, and Robinson’s character of Joshua— St: Stephen being a scriptural personage it is from the New Testament only that the Circumstances upon which his panegyric must be raised can be drawn— But these are so few and scanty that the ingenuity of the Preacher is tasked to spin out a full discourse from so slender a thread. St: Stephen’s history is an example for our virtues and a reproach to our vices—this is the Bishop’s doctrine, and is uniformly the same throughout the two volumes of Panegyrics, and funeral Orations— His divisions are always so much alike that they appear at length stiff and mechanical— He repeats his own sentiments too, which perhaps is unavoidable in a multitude of discourses on subjects so similar— I still find in Robinson scarcely any thing to remark.

12. I had the whole day without interruption, and finished letters to the Secretary of State and to Mr: Pitcairn— I hope in the course of the winter to have many such days of leisure, and pray that they may not pass away totally without improvement— I spent the Evening in my chamber—read in the third volume of Levesque’s History of Russia, and wrote a page of short hand— But for at least two hours of the time I was under such an excessive heaviness that I could scarcely hold the pen or follow the progress of the page— I have scarcely any recollection of what I read— What is the Cause of this sleepy propensity, and how shall it be overcome— It is a subtle thief of time, and baffles my best resolutions.— I find that it takes me an hour to write a page of short hand; and that it shortens the time, and the writing about one half— But the difficulty of reading is greater than that of writing it— I received this Evening a note from the Grand-Maitre des Cérémonies Narishkin to inform me that the Palace of Anitshkoff would be open to-morrow for Mrs: Adams to visit, if she pleases— I walked before dinner to the foundery—the weather yesterday and this day having been moderate the river is almost clear of ice, and the Bridges might be set up again.

13. At one O’Clock I went again with the Ladies to the Palace of Annitschkoff where we found the Grand Master of the Ceremonies Narischkin, Count Bussche, and General Watzdorf— I went all over the Palace the second time, from the Chapel to the steam and water baths under the ground floor, which is appropriated for the infant Prince, and his Nurses and attendants— The steam and water baths here as elsewhere are in different apartments— The bathing tub is of tin, and fitted into the floor in the middle of the room. over it is a vessel with holes like a cullender, from which the shower bath is poured when they choose it— The chapel is not yet consecrated; for which reason the Ladies were allowed to go into the Sanctuary— Mr: Narishkin told us however that it was a rigorous rule of the Greek church never to admit a woman into the Sanctuary. I remarked nothing on this visit but what I had seen before— The music room is circular and not large— The Prince’s Cabinet is elegant but without magnificence— There are no Carpets on the floors; but a very beautiful parquet— In the library there is a looking glass of one plate seven arsheens (16 feet 4 inches) high, and three arsheens (7 feet) wide.—a very magnificent thing, but out of its place— The bed-chamber is hung round with loose hangings of dark green velvet— The bed in the center of the room between the two doors— The Curtains sloping from the head to the foot of the bed. Among the time pieces of which there is one in almost every room, that which pleased me most was with a bronze figure of a Venus with a little Cupid bursting from an egg-shell which she holds in her hands— There is on the Sopha’s and Chairs too much gilding for my taste— The porcelain is not very beautiful and there is not much of it— The Siberian vase of Agate is very large and was very much admired. After going over the Palace I walked to the Foundery, and in returning upon the Quay of the Neva, met the Emperor; first on horseback, and the second time walking.— He then stop’d and spoke to me about the weather, and the appearance of the river— He asked me what was my habitual walk— I told him, commonly to the foundery— He asked where I lived— I told him in the New Street, in a Corner house partly fronting on the Moika— The Apartments in which Count Einsiedel had lived— He knew it by this description, and said the situation of the house was not good;—on account of walking— I said its situation was not remarkably advantageous; but that the walks in every part of the City were so convenient that it rendered the situation of a house almost immaterial— And pointing to the Quay on which we stood, I said it was one of the finest works ever made by men’s hands— He said they had a great advantage in possessing so much of the material, the granite rock; of which in Finland there were immense masses— That the rock on which the Statue of Peter the first was placed, was one of the smallest of those rocks which could have been found— That it formed blocks of whole mountains, and that there were places where it
was to be seen at once in both the stages of its first formation and of its last decay— I told him that I was acquainted with this Rock, and that my own Country produced it in great plenty— That it was considered as hardening and becoming more solid, by being exposed to the Air— He said it did for a certain period of time, after which it decayed, and crumbled into dust— But he added it would last a long time, and then looking at the wall bordering the quay, observed with a smile, “there is no danger for this, yet”— After I left him as I was walking home, I met and walked with Mr: Harris.— The Ladies went in the Evening to the Play— I spent it in reading Levesque, and in writing short-hand— Suffered again much drowsiness, but less than the last Evening— This morning at one O’Clock, my steward’s wife Marie Waldstein, a chambermaid of Mrs: Adams’s was brought to bed of a son.

14. Waldstein came to me this morning and requested me to stand godfather at the christening of his child, to-morrow at 2. O’Clock in the afternoon— And he also sollicited that the Ceremony might be performed in the parlour of our apartments; to both of which I consented— He made the request to Mrs: Adams to stand as God-mother, and invited Catherine and all the Gentlemen of the legation to attend— Mrs: Adams had a visit from Baroness Strogonoff, the wife of the late Russian Minister in Spain, who is separated from her husband, and lives in our house—in the apartments formerly occupied by Count Rzewuski— I walked before dinner to the foundery— The ice in the river has again formed and floats down in such masses, that to all appearance the river will be frozen over before to-morrow morning.— In the Evening I went to the German Play, and saw a Comedy of Kotzebue’s called Der Wirr Warr oder der Muthwillige, a foolish thing, with very little of the wit, and none of the interest, which are found in some of this author’s writings— It was however very short, and I did not see the first act— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us— The Ladies had cards in the Evening— I continue to copy in short hand— This Evening I finished the Treaty of Commerce of 19. Feby: 1810—between Portugal and England.

15. At 2. O’Clock the German Pastor of the Lutheran Church of St: Peters came and baptized Waldstein’s child, by the name of John, Charles Francis— We were all unacquainted with the customary formalities of this ceremony as practiced here— The Minister came attended by his Sexton— All our own family were present, and two young women of Waldstein’s acquaintance—and one man— The old nurse brought the child and requested me to hold it, as it was a son; which I did— Catherine Johnson was the Godmother, and not Mrs: Adams, it not being customary for man and wife to stand together— The Ceremony was very short—consisting of a prayer; by the Pastor—then he repeated the Lord’s prayer holding his right hand close upon the child’s head—then the creed—like the Apostles creed of the English Church; the baptism, on the child’s forehead, and a short concluding prayer— After which the Sexton brought a box for contribution for the poor, and the nurse handed round wine and Cake, and should have received something from every person— I had given fifty Rubles in the morning to Waldstein to make all these payments himself; but people will follow their usual forms—the old woman was satisfied with a five rouble bill, which I afterwards sent her— We had then a collation— Mr: Rodde called upon me and brought me a packet and several letters, which arrived at Reval, by the Barque Leopard, Captain Samuel Parker—a vessel of Lieutt: Governor Gray’s.— All the letters were for Mr: Everett and Mr: Gray, excepting one to me from his father— He recommends Captain Parker again to me for advice— I had some further conversation on this business with Mr: F. Gray— I walked on the quay before dinner, and found as I had expected that the river was completely frozen over—the same day as last year.— At 9 this Evening I went to the Ball and Spectacle at the French Ambassador’s— The Plays performed were La Revanche—and a Vaudeville called La Hotte—not so agreeable as the last weeks performances— I came home soon after the Play was over, between 12. and 1. O’Clock.

16. I called at 3. O’Clock in the afternoon upon Mr: Rodde at his lodgings at Demuth’s hotel, and gave him the letters for America, which he is to send to Riga, to go from thence to New-York by a vessel now loading— Walked on the quay of the Neva, and found numbers of people, crossing the river upon the ice— Dined at Baron Blome’s with a Company of eighteen or twenty Gentlemen— Principally persons whom I have met there before— Count Fagnani a Chamberlain of the king of Italy, and Count d’Uggles, a young Swedish nobleman, now in the family of Count Stedingk, were the only strangers— Baron Blome has an excellent collection of maps, and I looked over particularly a map of the kingdom of Naples, Sicily and Malta, by Bacler d’Albe—the right hand, General Watzdorf calls him, of the Emperor Napoleon for his topography— I pass’d the Evening at home, writing short-hand— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Jones were here— Mr: Gray unwell— My footman John was this day discharged from the Police, and I dismiss’d him from my service.

17. Mr: Rodde called upon me again this morning, and brought some letters from Boston which came in another vessel of Mr: Gray’s arrived at Revel—the Brig William— I had one letter from Mr: Gray, and one from Dr: Waterhouse— Visit also from Mr: Montréal— Walk to the foundery before dinner and Evening Cards— I finished this Evening in short-hand the Treaty of Alliance between Great-Britain and Portugal.

18. Mr: Grammann sent me a day or two ago a number of English Newspapers; and this morning getting engaged in the perusal of them, it absorbed the whole portion of the day during which there was any daylight— I walked to the foundery— Read Massillon’s panegyric of St: Thomas Aquinas the Angelic Doctor— This is one of the schoolmen of the 13th: century, and a most voluminous writer of books now read by nobody— It is one of the bishops figurative discourses; crowded with scriptural allusions quaintly applied— In the Evening I read Robinson’s Characters of Eli and of Samuel— Mr: J. S. Smith and Mr: Jones were here.

19. Having no special occupation of immediate necessity pressing upon me, I find a strong propensity to remissness, growing upon me, and this day lost a great proportion of my time— I consulted however Martens’s Guide Diplomatique, and the English Collection of Treaties, to look into the Treaties of Commerce between Russia and the other European Powers. Walking on the Quay I met and walked with General Pardo, who told me some political news, upon the accuracy of which I do not trust— All our Gentlemen dined with us— In the Evening I went to the little Theatre with the Ladies, and saw Mercier’s Deserteur, with the Opera of Philippe et Georgette— After which we spent the Evening and supped at General Betancourts; where there was music and dancing untill about one in the morning when we came home— Madame Colombi, and Miss Caroline Betancourt played on the Harp— Miss Adeline Betancourt upon the tamborine— Monsr: Lepin upon the Forte Piano. The Chevalier Navarro, Mr: Harris and Mr: Jones were there.

20. This day slip’d away from me still more idly than yesterday— Mr: Harris called upon me this morning— He told me that his fees of Office this year consisting of two dollars for each paper authenticated by the Consular seal, excepting the certificates of goods being landed, for each of which he has one dollar 50 Cents, amounted to 4800 dollars; but he says they will scarcely pay his Office-Rent, Clerk-hire and postage— He reckons indeed 1500 dollars a year for a Clerk— I walked before dinner to the foundery— Read Levesque in the Evening; and merely to continue the practice of writing in short hand, made a translation of part of the Treaty of Bartenstein, between Russia and Prussia— Had Cards at the close of the Evening.

21. In seeking an occupation for the few leisure moments which I shall have, I took up Dinsdale’s Isocrates, and read the first Oration—to Demonicus— It is more properly a letter containing advice to a young man for his conduct in the world than an Oration. The advice is generally good; but there is in the translation nothing of that mellifluous sweetness for which the original is famed— Some part of his Counsel resembles that of Chesterfield; but without any of his immorality— The Ladies pass’d the evening at Mr: Colombi’s; and I went there myself about 10, and stayed to supper— Madame Betancourt and her daughters were there; but not the General— Mr: Navarro and Mr: Harris also were of the Company—

22. Morning visits from Mr: Harris and Mr: Montréal. Mr: Harris brought me some papers respecting the property which has come into his hands of a Mr: Irwin who perished by a shipwreck in coming from Revel to St: Petersburg, the night that we came out from Fleckeroe— His widow, and his partner in Trade both claim the balance of the property saved from the wreck— I wrote a letter to Mr: Malbone, and a certificate for him according to his request— In the Evening I went with the Ladies to the French Ambassador’s weekly party— We went about ten O’Clock and came home a little before two in the morning.— We saw two little Operas—Les Pages du Duc de Vendome, and La Tableau Parlant— In the first of which there were four women who performed the parts of Pages, and in the second all the male parts were performed by women, and all the female parts by men, which makes the whole performance very indecent— The company was rather more numerous than usual.

23. In consequence of breaking in so largely upon the Night, as I have done three days of the last four, I find the Night now in its turn breaking in upon the day— I did not rise this morning untill near Noon; and accordingly all my customary
occupations were discomposed— I had barely breakfasted when it became necessary to take my morning walk— I was obliged even to shorten that, and 4. O’Clock went to dine with Count Romanzoff— It was a diplomatic dinner, given to Count St: Julien, on his having presented his credentials as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from the Emperor of Austria— The Count went hand in hand with the French Ambassador into the dinner room and was seated at the left hand of Count Romanzoff. I got seated between the Secretary general of the Empire Mr: Speranski and a Senator whom I did not know— I had not been before acquainted with Mr: Speranski, but entered into conversation with him and found him agreeable— Madame de Betancourt and her daughters, Madame Colombi and her Sister Miss Clementine de Bode, Mr: Navarro, Don Francisco Colombi, Mr: Harris, Mr Jones, and all our own family pass’d the Evening and supp’d with us—the young Ladies and Gentlemen danced untill near two in the morning— Mr: Grammann called on me this morning and brought me a letter from Captain William Welsh, who is arrived at Liebau in a vessel of Mr: Gray’s— It enclosed likewise a letter from my mother of 25. July.

24. Rose again this morning very late; though not quite so much so as yesterday— But immediately after breakfast I called at Mr: Colombi’s Counting-House— He was himself unwell and I did not see him— I presented Mr: Daschkoff’s bill for payment; but the Clerks not knowing at what rate the exchange was to be made up desired me to call or send the Bill again this Evening, or on Monday—the bill is for 4000 guilders current of Holland to be paid in Assignation-Bills at the exchange of the time when the bill becomes payable— I then called at Baron Blome’s, and he not being at home I left the letter for Mr: Malbone at his house— He promised me he would forward it with his despatches— I then took my usual morning walk, which brought it to the dusk of Evening— Soon after I got home, Mr: Colombi’s Clerk brought me a note from him with 9846. Roubles 15. Copeeks for the Amount of Mr: Daschkoff’s bill, which I sent him with a receipt upon it— I reserved of these 6000 Rubles to pay for a years rent to Mr: Plinkey my present Landlord—he called upon me the day before-yesterday with a lease, which he wishes to have executed between us, and which should indeed have been executed before we came into the house— By the terms of the lease, half a year’s rent is always to be paid in advance, which is the custom of this Country— And as I have not yet paid any rent I told Plinkey I would pay him the full year’s rent at once, which will bring me the half year in advance— Mr: Everett did not dine with us— In the Evening we had Cards with the Ladies.

25. It was again about twelve O’Clock when I rose, and the day was accordingly short— Mr: Harris dined, and spent part of the Evening with us— Madame de Betancourt was here in the morning— The Ladies in the Evening paid a visit to Madame Narischkin the wife of the Grand Veneur— Mr: Jones and Mr: Tilden were here but I did not see them— I read Massillon’s Sermon upon the day of a Saint and Martyr—the Patron of a Church— It is the last in the volume of Panegyrics, and excepting one eloquent passage, is not worth much— It is remarkable that neither the Sermon itself nor the title mentions the name of the Saint, nor is it possible from any thing contained in it, to infer who the person was— I read also Robinson’s character of Saul.

26. Mr: Raimbert called on me this morning, and spoke of a meeting of the merchants last Saturday, at which it was proposed that payment should be suspended for six months of the numerous bills drawn upon Hamburg within the last two months which have come and are coming back protested. I dined at Monsieur de Laval’s; who lives at present in the house of the late Prince Beloselsky— The Company about fifteen persons, chiefly Russians—and two Ladies; a Countess Schuwaloff, and Countess Soltikoff— I was introduced to Prince Dolgorucki late the Russian Minister in Holland. In the Evening I paid a visit to General Betancourt— I saw his Lady and Daughters, but not himself— Mr: & Madame Gorgoli were there; also upon a visit— On returning home with the family and Mr: Jones, I closed the Evening at Cards.

27. Mr: Patterson of New-York, and Mr: Bridge of Boston came this morning to see me— They arrived in two of the vessels which were coming from Gottenburg here, and which were obliged to enter at Revel— They have found difficulties in obtaining admission; and come to me for assistance— Mr: Harris was also here, and mentioned a conversation that he had yesterday with Mr: Borel, from which he entertains great hopes for the ensuing year— I met and walked with General Pardo, as far as the Summer-gardens— He says that he has received but two despatches from his Court these five months— Although the custom of the Court was always to write once a week— In the Evening, I read something of Palmer’s short-hand; and began the fourth Volume of Levesque’s History of Russia; where the establishment of the house of Romanoff on the throne commences— Mr: J. S. Smith was here and we had Cards.

28. Visit this morning from Count Luxbourg, with whom I rode in his sleigh to the Fontanka, and then walked round to the Palace Corner on the Quay— We met the Emperor who stop’d and spoke to us about the weather— Luxbourg told me that he had just come from Count Stedingk’s; and that Sweden at the peremptory requisition of Mr: Alquier the French Minister, had declared War against England. The Ladies went in the Evening, with Baroness Strogonoff, and Madame de Betancourt to Countess Golovin’s— I pass’d it at home, and read in Levesque the reign’s of Michael, Alexis and Fedor the predecessors of Peter the great, of the Romanoff family.— I also made some further application to the practice of Short-hand.

29. This morning I received two notes successively from Count Romanzoff, the first appointing 1/2 past eleven o’clock to-morrow morning, as the time when he would see me; and the second postponing the conference untill 9. in the Evening; and requesting me then to meet him at his own house on the English quay— I met and walked with General Pardo— While at dinner I received a letter from Captain Hopkins at Archangel giving a long account of the shipwreck which he suffered in attempting to sail from that Port— Mr: Harris was with us early this Evening, and told me that Mr: Jewett had met with the same misfortune of being shipwrecked in going from Cronstadt— Mr: J. S. Smith was also with us in the Evening— I went late to the French Ambassador’s weekly party—they Play had begun— Le Confident par hazard; a Comedy—which was succeeded by another, called Guerre ouverte ou Ruse contre Ruse—a translation from a Spanish Comedy of Moretto; who General Pardo says is one of their greatest comic Poets— For the vis comice he considers him superior to Calderon— I came home soon after the Play finished; about 2 in the morning.

30. I was up again about noon, and had scarcely time to write two short letters before Night came on. I had a visit however from Mr: Montreal who told me of the demands lately made here by the French Government; among which was that of dismissing all the Frenchmen who are Officers in the Russian service— In the Evening Mr: Harris and Mr: Plummer were here— At 9. O’Clock, I went to Count Romanzoff’s house on the quay—and met him there— His Aunt Madam Narishkin, an old lady of eighty years of age lives there, and being infirm in health the Count passes much of his time with her— I told him I had requested to see him on account of a number of American vessels which had arrived at Revel, at Baltic Port, at Riga and at Liebau since the Navigation at Cronstadt to which they were bound has been closed— Several of them were in the first instance admitted without difficulty; but afterwards an order had been issued to suspend the admission of the rest, and to prevent the unloading of those which had been admitted untill further orders— That the persons interested in these vessels and cargoes were alarmed and uneasy under these difficulties, and some of them had applied to me for my interposition in their favour— The Count said he supposed that some suspicion might have arisen from the supposition that these vessels belonged to the great convoy of six hundred sail which had been so long signalized by the Emperor Napoleon, and which it was said had now entered the Baltic, coming from Gothenburg. I told him that they had actually come from Gothenburg, and probably belonged to that convoy— But I trusted he would not suspect me of attempting to shelter under the American name any traffic or property prohibited by the Laws of this Country— He said that he could hardly express to my face what he thought upon this subject; but it was certainly nothing distrustful of me— I then said that I had a list of these vessels which I was perfectly assured were bona-fide American— That I had received letters by several of them from my friends in America, of the most recent dates which had come to hand— That the Captain of one of them, the Supercargoes of several, and the owners of almost all were personally known to me as Citizens of the United States, and that with regard to them all I had such information as left me no doubt that they were really Americans, and that all proper Confidence might be given to their papers.— He desired me to write him unofficially a short letter on this subject, stating all these Circumstances, and intimated that the difficulties that had been raised would easily be removed; promising to lay the matter as soon as possible before the Emperor— He then entered into a general Conversation, and asked me to give him my candid Opinion upon the Emperor Napoleon’s tariff of 5. August last; and upon his decree for burning all merchandize of English manufacture— I did accordingly give him my opinion fully and freely with respect to both— The Count did not explicitly say that he agreed with me in opinion;
but I am convinced he can hardly entertain a different one— He told me that he had received a Courier from Sweden, with the Account of the determination there to declare War against England, for which the french Minister had allowed only five days. We had also much Conversation upon the news—the armies in Portugal—the king of England’s illness, and other common topics—not of sufficient interest to be written down. I was with him about two hours— On returning home I found Mr: Jones who soon afterwards withdrew.

Day. The Sun rises now about nine in the morning, it is scarcely day-light at eight; and I seldom rise from bed before ten— Read five chapters in the French Bible, with Ostervald’s reflections— Breakfast— Noon has arrived— A visitor or two brings it easily to three O’Clock— Or I write a letter; long or short, or a day’s record in this Book and the day is gone— It darkens soon after two O’Clock, even in the few days when the Sun is seen; which is upon the average about once a week— The six others there is a gloomy half-darkness through the day— So that from ten untill 2. I can just see to write— From 3. to 5. I walk— Dine at 5 and sit usually untill seven— Spend usually two or three hours after dinner in my cabinet— Reading Levesque, or writing short hand, or any thing that must not be postponed. From 9 or 10 at Night untill one or two in the morning I pass in Company abroad or at home, or at Cards with the Ladies— The difficulty of writing any thing and the disgust at the occupation grows upon me in a distressing manner. And I feel more and more every day the importunity of miscellaneous Company.
